facts.text: Appellant is resident of Simla and forest contractor

anchor.surface_text: The facts are shortly as follows The appellant, who is a resident of Simla, is a forest companytractor and had taken certain

facts.text: Appellant took forests on lease in 1942-43 in Jubbal State for exploitation

anchor.surface_text: tractor and had taken certain forests on lease in 1942-43 in the erstwhile Indian State of Jubbal for exploitation. The work

facts.text: Work of felling trees and extraction of timber continued up to 1945-46

anchor.surface_text: of felling of trees and extraction of timber companytinued up to 1945-46. No profit or loss account had been prepared for

facts.text: Consolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account drawn up for four years

anchor.surface_text: each of the aforesaid four years separately, but a companysolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account had been drawn

facts.text: Income from forest business shown at 10% net on sales in IT returns

anchor.surface_text: up for all the four years. In the appellants Income-tax returns, the income from the forest business was calculated and sh

facts.text: Appellant sold timber in 1942-43 in Jubbal to Sukh Dial Jagat Ram for Rs. 1,91,000

anchor.surface_text: in companyrse of the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1943- 44, it transpired that the appellant, who was resident and ordinarily resident in British India, had in the relevant accounting year 1942-43 sold in Jubbal a quantity of timber in one lot to a single party named Sukh Dial Jagat Ram

facts.text: ITO assessment order dated 1948-02-02 held profit on sale Rs. 20,967

anchor.surface_text: sident and ordinarily resident in British India, had in the relevant accounting year 1942-43 sold in Jubbal a quantity of timber in one lot to a single party named Sukh Dial Jagat Ram, a firm carrying on business in Abdullapore in the district of Ambala, for a sum of Rs. 1,91,000  rupees one lakh ninety-  one thousand . By his assessment order dated the 2nd February, 1948, the Income-tax officer held that on the sale of timber of the value of Rs. 1,91,000 during the relevant accounting period 1942-43, the appellant had made a profit of Rs. 20,967.

facts.text: No part of sale proceeds received during 1942-43

anchor.surface_text: By his assessment order dated the 2nd February, 1948, the Income-tax officer held that on the sale of timber of the value of Rs. 1,91,000 during the relevant accounting period 1942-43, the appellant had made a profit of Rs. 20,967. As, however, numberpart of the sale proceeds was received during the relevant accounting period

facts.text: Profits for 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46 determined by ITO

anchor.surface_text: the income from the forest business, less the statutory exemption of Rs. 4,500 was taken into companysideration only for the purpose of fixing the rate. The profits made on sales during the three succeeding accounting periods 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46 were also determined by the Income-tax officer as indicated in his assessment order.

facts.text: AAC on appeal reduced profit for 1942-43 from Rs. 19,767 and proportionately for others

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the appellant, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed certain expenses, which had been disallowed by the Income-tax Officer, so that the total income from the forest business was reduced. The profit on the sale of timber during the accounting year 1942-43 was accordingly reduced from Rs. 19,767 and the profits for the three succeeding accounting years were proportionately reduced.

facts.text: Tribunal further reduced profit by Rs. 5,000, final for 1942-43 Rs. 18,758

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, the profits were further reduced by the allowance of a further sum of Rs. 5,000 so that the profit of the accounting year 1942-43 was finally ascertained and determined to be Rs. 18,758.

facts.text: Receipts out of Rs.1,91,000: Rs.1,25,000 cash in Jubbal, Rs.29,000 cash in British India to appellant, Rs.3,000 to Sita Ram in British India

anchor.surface_text: In companyrse of assessment for the assessment year 1944-45, it transpired that out of the purchase price of Rs. 1,91,000 for timber sold in the accounting year 1942-43 in the following manner Rs. 1,25,000 received in cash in Jubbal State. Rs. 29,000 received in cash by the appellant in British India. Rs. 3,000 paid in cash in British India to a companytractor named Sita Ram, who was a creditor of the appellant.

facts.text: ITO viewed Rs.32,000 received in 1943-44 as entire profit from 1942-43 sale, assessable u/s 4(1)(b)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer took the view that the sums of Rs. 29,000 and Rs. 3,000, aggregating to Rs. 32,000, received in the relevant accounting year 1943-44 included the entire profit that had accrued or arisen to the appellant on the sale of timber in 1942-43 for Rs. 1,91,000 and such profit was assessable to tax under section 4  1   b   iii  as income, profits and gains accrued or arisen to the appellant without British India before the beginning of the previous year, that is to say, in the accounting year 1942-43 and brought into or received in British India during the relevant accounting year 1943-44 and assessed accordingly.

facts.text: AAC upheld ITO decision

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the appellant the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the decision of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld, held constructive remittances of profits

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal by the appellant the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal took the same view and dismissed the appeal. The Appellate Tribunal, in agreement with the Income-tax authorities, held that the two payments in British India had been made by the purchaser according to the instructions of the appellant and were companysequently tantamount to companystructive remittances of those amounts from Jubbal State to British India and that the profits, in the absence of any evidence adduced by the appellant to the companytrary, must be regarded as remittances of profits.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Tribunal u/s 66(1), listed questions, dismissed 1950-08-07 except withdrawn one

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the decision of the Appellate Tribunal, the appellant applied to the Appellate Tribunal under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, praying that the Appellate Tribunal might state a case and refer to the High Count the following questions of law ... The Appellate Tribunal by its order dated 7th August, 1950, dismissed the application in respect of the other questions.

facts.text: High Court u/s66(2) dismissed application 1953-06-25

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied to the High Count of Punjab under section 66  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, ... By its order dated the 25th June, 1953, the High Court dismissed the application with companyts.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds profit accrued in 1942-43 on sale, amount Rs.18,758 final

anchor.surface_text: There can be numbergetting away from the fact that profit accrues or arises on the sale, which in this case took place in 1942-43. Whatever profit there was, it certainly accrued or arose in that year. The profit on the sale of timber in 1942-43 has since been ascertained at Rs. 18,758. This finding is final and the appellant cannot go behind it.

facts.text: Presumption that remittances are profits unless contrary shown

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the tribunal was quite companyrect in saying that, in the circumstances, the payment was undoubtedly a companystructive remittance of money by the appellant from Jubbal to his British India office.

arguments.claim: Profit accrues or arises on the sale in 1942-43, not on recoupment

anchor.surface_text: There can be no getting away from the fact that profit accrues or arises on the sale, which in this case took place in 1942-43. Whatever profit there was, it certainly accrued or arose in that year. The profit on the sale of timber in 1942-43 has since been ascertained at Rs. 18,758. This finding is final and the appellant cannot go behind it.

arguments.claim: Remittances from foreign business presumed profits unless contrary shown

anchor.surface_text: There being this profit, as eventually ascertained, the presumption, according to the cases referred to in the judgment under appeal, will be that the remittances of money from foreign business to British India must be of profits, unless the contrary were shown by the appellant.

arguments.claim: Appellant failed to discharge onus to show remittances not profits

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the appellant did not discharge the onus that was on him and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was quite correct in coming to the conclusion that the sum of Rs. 32,000 included the profits made on the sale of timber for Rs. 1,91,000 in the accounting year 1942-43.

arguments.claim: Payments tantamount to constructive remittances as per instructions

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the tribunal was quite correct in saying that, in the circumstances, the payment was undoubtedly a constructive remittance of money by the appellant from Jubbal to his British India office.

arguments.claim: No real or substantial question of law; High Court justified in dismissing u/s 66(2)

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and circumstances of this case, no real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court was justified in dismissing the appellants application under section 66(2) of the India Income-tax Act, 1922.

holdings.text: Profit accrues or arises on the sale, which took place in 1942-43. The profit on the sale of timber in 1942-43 has been ascertained at Rs. 18,758. This finding is final and the appellant cannot go behind it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court rejects argument that profit arises only after recoupment of entire outlay; accrual occurs at time of sale as per established principle.

holdings.text: There being this profit as eventually ascertained, the presumption will be that the remittances of money from foreign business to British India must be of profits, unless the contrary were shown by the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents cited in High Court judgment applying presumption to remittances from foreign business.

holdings.text: The appellant did not discharge the onus that was on him and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was quite correct in coming to the conclusion that the sum of Rs. 32,000 included the profits made on the sale of timber for Rs. 1,91,000 in the accounting year 1942-43.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant failed to adduce evidence rebutting presumption despite opportunity; Tribunal's conclusion upheld.

holdings.text: The payment was undoubtedly a constructive remittance of money by the appellant from Jubbal to his British India office. Similar considerations apply to the payment of Rs. 29,000.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances indicate purchaser acted on appellant's instructions, making purchaser agent for remittance; direct evidence lacking but inferred.

holdings.text: The receipt of Rs. 32,000 has been correctly held to be a constructive remittance from Jubbal State to British India.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit does not deny instructions; surrounding circumstances justify Tribunal's finding of instructions and constructive remittance.

holdings.text: The assessee remitted the entire profits of the account year 1942-43 in the sum of Rs. 32,000.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption applies fully to constructive remittance equivalent to direct; no evidence to rebut.

holdings.text: The whole of the profit of Rs. 18,758 cannot be regarded as having been brought into or received in British India? No, entire profit included as per presumption.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects proportionality; constructive remittance treated as direct, attracting full presumption; Turner Morrison inapplicable.

holdings.text: No real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court was justified in dismissing the appellant's application under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All factual and legal findings justified; no error warranting reference.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla in support of this companytention. There is numberforce in this companytention, because it may well be that the appellant knew that his party was solvent and sound and in anticipation of the realization of the entire amount, the appellant remitted the entire profit, which he calculated would eventually companye in, to British India.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla
precedents.cited_proposition: no profit can be said to have been received unless and until the entire outlay is recouped; amounts remitted by agent were initial outlay and no question of profit could arise until entire outlay recovered
precedents.cited_holding: the amounts remitted by the agent were the initial outlay and numberquestion of profit companyld arise until the entire outlay was recovered

precedents.citation: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal. That decision has really numberapplication to the facts of the present case. As already stated the two amounts were paid in British India at the direction of the appellant, which means the same thing as if the payment had been by the purchaser and received by the appellant from his purchaser in Jubbal and then remitted by the appellant through the purchaser as his agent to himself and his creditor in British India.

precedents.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: a proportionate part of the total profit attributable to Rs. 32,000 should be regarded as having been included in that sum
